question.content:
We want to find the zeros of this polynomial:

$p(x)=2x^3-x^2-8x+4$

**Plot all the zeros ($x$-intercepts) of the polynomial in the interactive graph.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
First, we need to factor the polynomial entirely.

Then, we can find the zeros by looking for all the $x$-values that make any of the factors equal to zero.

## Factoring

As a first step, we can factor the polynomial using grouping:

$\begin{align}
p(x)&=2x^3-x^2-8x+4
\\\\
&=x^2(2x-1)-4(2x-1)
\\\\
&=(x^2-4)(2x-1)
\end{align}$

Now we can further factor $(x^2-4)$ using the difference of squares pattern:

$\begin{align}
&\phantom{=}\blueD{(x^2-4)}(2x-1)
\\\\
&=\blueD{(x+2)(x-2)}(2x-1)
\end{align}$

## Finding the zeros

So this is the factored form of $p$:

$p(x)=(x+2)(x-2)(2x-1)$

This table contains all the factors of $p$ and the $x$-values that make them equal to zero.

Factor | Zero
:-: | :-:
$(x+2)$ | $x=-2$
$(x-2)$ | $x=2$
$(2x-1)$ | $x=\dfrac12$

We found that the zeros of $p$ are $x=-2$, $x=2$, and $x=\dfrac12$, which means the graph has $x$-intercepts at $(-2,0)$, $(2,0)$, and $\left(\dfrac12,0\right)$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: An x y coordinate plane. The x-axis scales by one half. Points are at (negative two, zero), (zero, zero), and (three, zero).

question.content:
We want to find the zeros of this polynomial:

$p(x)=2x^3+5x^2-2x-5$

**Plot all the zeros ($x$-intercepts) of the polynomial in the interactive graph.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
First, we need to factor the polynomial entirely.

Then, we can find the zeros by looking for all the $x$-values that make any of the factors equal to zero.

## Factoring

As a first step, we can factor the polynomial using grouping:

$\begin{align}
p(x)&=2x^3+5x^2-2x-5
\\\\
&=x^2(2x+5)-1(2x+5)
\\\\
&=(x^2-1)(2x+5)
\end{align}$

Now we can further factor $(x^2-1)$ using the difference of squares pattern:

$\begin{align}
&\phantom{=}\blueD{(x^2-1)}(2x+5)
\\\\
&=\blueD{(x+1)(x-1)}(2x+5)
\end{align}$

## Finding the zeros

So this is the factored form of $p$:

$p(x)=(x+1)(x-1)(2x+5)$

This table contains all the factors of $p$ and the $x$-values that make them equal to zero.

Factor | Zero
:-: | :-:
$(x+1)$ | $x=-1$
$(x-1)$ | $x=1$
$(2x+5)$ | $x=-\dfrac52$

We found that the zeros of $p$ are $x=-1$, $x=1$, and $x=-\dfrac52$, which means the graph has $x$-intercepts at $(-1,0)$, $(1,0)$, and $\left(-\dfrac52,0\right)$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: An x y coordinate plane. The x-axis scales by one half. Points are at (negative two and a half, zero), (negative one, zero), and (one, zero).

question.content:
We want to find the zeros of this polynomial:

$p(x)=2x^3+3x^2-18x-27$

**Plot all the zeros ($x$-intercepts) of the polynomial in the interactive graph.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
First, we need to factor the polynomial entirely.

Then, we can find the zeros by looking for all the $x$-values that make any of the factors equal to zero.

## Factoring

As a first step, we can factor the polynomial using grouping:

$\begin{align}
p(x)&=2x^3+3x^2-18x-27
\\\\
&=x^2(2x+3)-9(2x+3)
\\\\
&=(x^2-9)(2x+3)
\end{align}$

Now we can further factor $(x^2-9)$ using the difference of squares pattern:

$\begin{align}
&\phantom{=}\blueD{(x^2-9)}(2x+3)
\\\\
&=\blueD{(x+3)(x-3)}(2x+3)
\end{align}$

## Finding the zeros

So this is the factored form of $p$:

$p(x)=(x+3)(x-3)(2x+3)$

This table contains all the factors of $p$ and the $x$-values that make them equal to zero.

Factor | Zero
:-: | :-:
$(x+3)$ | $x=-3$
$(x-3)$ | $x=3$
$(2x+3)$ | $x=-\dfrac32$

We found that the zeros of $p$ are $x=-3$, $x=3$, and $x=-\dfrac32$, which means the graph has $x$-intercepts at $(-3,0)$, $(3,0)$, and $\left(-\dfrac32,0\right)$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: An x y coordinate plane. The x-axis scales by one half. Points are at (negative three, zero), (negative one and a half, zero), and (three, zero).

question.content:
We want to find the zeros of this polynomial:

$p(x)=3x^3-3x^2-18x$

**Plot all the zeros ($x$-intercepts) of the polynomial in the interactive graph.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
First, we need to factor the polynomial entirely.

Then, we can find the zeros by looking for all the $x$-values that make any of the factors equal to zero.

## Finding the zeros

So this is the factored form of $p$:

$p(x)=3x(x-3)(x+2)$

This table contains all the factors of $p$ and the $x$-values that make them equal to zero.

Factor | Zero
:-: | :-:
$3x$ | $x=0$
$(x-3)$ | $x=3$
$(x+2)$ | $x=-2$

We found that the zeros of $p$ are $x=0$, $x=3$, and $x=-2$, which means the graph has $x$-intercepts at $(0,0)$, $(3,0)$, and $(-2,0)$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: An x y coordinate plane. The x-axis scales by one half. Points are at (one, zero), (two, zero), and (three and a half, zero).

question.content:
We want to find the zeros of this polynomial:

$p(x)=2x^3+4x^2-6x$

**Plot all the zeros ($x$-intercepts) of the polynomial in the interactive graph.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
First, we need to factor the polynomial entirely.

Then, we can find the zeros by looking for all the $x$-values that make any of the factors equal to zero.

## Finding the zeros

So this is the factored form of $p$:

$p(x)=2x(x+3)(x-1)$

This table contains all the factors of $p$ and the $x$-values that make them equal to zero.

Factor | Zero
:-: | :-:
$2x$ | $x=0$
$(x+3)$ | $x=-3$
$(x-1)$ | $x=1$

We found that the zeros of $p$ are $x=0$, $x=-3$, and $x=1$, which means the graph has $x$-intercepts at $(0,0)$, $(-3,0)$, and $(1,0)$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: An x y coordinate plane. The x-axis scales by one half. Points are at (negative three, zero), (zero, zero), and (one, zero).

question.content:
We want to find the zeros of this polynomial:

$p(x)=5x^3-5x^2-10x$

**Plot all the zeros ($x$-intercepts) of the polynomial in the interactive graph.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
First, we need to factor the polynomial entirely.

Then, we can find the zeros by looking for all the $x$-values that make any of the factors equal to zero.

## Finding the zeros

So this is the factored form of $p$:

$p(x)=5x(x-2)(x+1)$

This table contains all the factors of $p$ and the $x$-values that make them equal to zero.

Factor | Zero
:-: | :-:
$5x$ | $x=0$
$(x-2)$ | $x=2$
$(x+1)$ | $x=-1$

We found that the zeros of $p$ are $x=0$, $x=2$, and $x=-1$, which means the graph has $x$-intercepts at $(0,0)$, $(2,0)$, and $(-1,0)$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: An x y coordinate plane. The x-axis scales by one half. Points are at (negative one, zero), (zero, zero), and (two, zero).

question.content:
We want to find the zeros of this polynomial:

$p(x)=(2x^2+7x+5)(x-3)$

**Plot all the zeros ($x$-intercepts) of the polynomial in the interactive graph.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
First, we need to factor the polynomial entirely.

Then, we can find the zeros by looking for all the $x$-values that make any of the factors equal to zero.

## Factoring

$p$ is already partially factored. We can further factor $(2x^2+7x+5)$ using the grouping method:

$\begin{align}
p(x)&=(2x^2+7x+5)(x-3)
\\\\
&=(2x^2+2x+5x+5)(x-3)
\\\\
&=\big(2x(x+1)+5(x+1)\big)(x-3)
\\\\
&=(2x+5)(x+1)(x-3)
\end{align}$

## Finding the zeros

So this is the factored form of $p$:

$p(x)=(2x+5)(x+1)(x-3)$

This table contains all the factors of $p$ and the $x$-values that make them equal to zero.

Factor | Zero
:-: | :-:
$(2x+5)$ | $x=-\dfrac52$
$(x+1)$ | $x=-1$
$(x-3)$ | $x=3$

We found that the zeros of $p$ are $x=-\dfrac52$, $x=-1$, and $x=3$, which means the graph has $x$-intercepts at $\left(-\dfrac52,0\right)$, $\left(-1,0\right)$, and $\left(3,0\right)$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: An x y coordinate plane. The x-axis scales by one half. Points are at (negative two and half, zero), (negative one, zero), and (three, zero).

question.content:
We want to find the zeros of this polynomial:

$p(x)=(x+2)(2x^2+3x-9)$

**Plot all the zeros ($x$-intercepts) of the polynomial in the interactive graph.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
First, we need to factor the polynomial entirely.

Then, we can find the zeros by looking for all the $x$-values that make any of the factors equal to zero.

## Factoring

$p$ is already partially factored. We can further factor $(2x^2+3x-9)$ using the grouping method:

$\begin{align}
p(x)&=(x+2)(2x^2+3x-9)
\\\\
&=(x+2)(2x^2+6x-3x-9)
\\\\
&=(x+2)\big(2x(x+3)-3(x+3)\big)
\\\\
&=(x+2)(2x-3)(x+3)
\end{align}$

## Finding the zeros

So this is the factored form of $p$:

$p(x)=(x+2)(2x-3)(x+3)$

This table contains all the factors of $p$ and the $x$-values that make them equal to zero.

Factor | Zero
:-: | :-:
$(x+2)$ | $x=-2$
$(2x-3)$ | $x=\dfrac32$
$(x+3)$ | $x=-3$

We found that the zeros of $p$ are $x=-2$, $x=\dfrac32$, and $x=-3$, which means the graph has $x$-intercepts at $\left(-2,0\right)$, $\left(\dfrac32,0\right)$, and $\left(-3,0\right)$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: An x y coordinate plane. The x-axis scales by one half. Points are at (negative three, zero), (negative two, zero), and (one and a half, zero).

question.content:
We want to find the zeros of this polynomial:

$p(x)=(2x^2-9x+7)(x-2)$

**Plot all the zeros ($x$-intercepts) of the polynomial in the interactive graph.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
First, we need to factor the polynomial entirely.

Then, we can find the zeros by looking for all the $x$-values that make any of the factors equal to zero.

## Factoring

$p$ is already partially factored. We can further factor $(2x^2-9x+7)$ using the grouping method:

$\begin{align}
p(x)&=(2x^2-9x+7)(x-2)
\\\\
&=(2x^2-2x-7x+7)(x-2)
\\\\
&=\big(2x(x-1)-7(x-1)\big)(x-2)
\\\\
&=(2x-7)(x-1)(x-2)
\end{align}$

## Finding the zeros

So this is the factored form of $p$:

$p(x)=(2x-7)(x-1)(x-2)$

This table contains all the factors of $p$ and the $x$-values that make them equal to zero.

Factor | Zero
:-: | :-:
$(2x-7)$ | $x=\dfrac72$
$(x-1)$ | $x=1$
$(x-2)$ | $x=2$

We found that the zeros of $p$ are $x=\dfrac72$, $x=1$, and $x=2$, which means the graph has $x$-intercepts at $\left(\dfrac72,0\right)$, $\left(1,0\right)$, and $\left(2,0\right)$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: An x y coordinate plane. The x-axis scales by one half. Points are at (one, zero), (two, zero), and (three and a half, zero).

question.content:
We want to find the zeros of this polynomial:

$p(x)=(x^2-1)(x^2-5x+6)$

**Plot all the zeros ($x$-intercepts) of the polynomial in the interactive graph.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
First, we need to factor the polynomial entirely.

Then, we can find the zeros by looking for all the $x$-values that make any of the factors equal to zero.

## Finding the zeros

So this is the factored form of $p$:

$p(x)=(x+1)(x-1)(x-3)(x-2)$

This table contains all the factors of $p$ and the $x$-values that make them equal to zero.

Factor | Zero
:-: | :-:
$(x+1)$ | $x=-1$
$(x-1)$ | $x=1$
$(x-3)$ | $x=3$
$(x-2)$ | $x=2$

We found that the zeros of $p$ are $x=-1$, $x=1$, $x=3$, and $x=2$, which means the graph has $x$-intercepts at $\left(-1,0\right)$, $\left(1,0\right)$, $\left(3,0\right)$, and $\left(2,0\right)$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: An x y coordinate plane. The x-axis scales by one half. Points are at (negative one, zero), (one, zero), (two, zero), and (three, zero).

question.content:
We want to find the zeros of this polynomial:

$p(x)=(x^2+4x+3)(x^2-4)$

**Plot all the zeros ($x$-intercepts) of the polynomial in the interactive graph.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
First, we need to factor the polynomial entirely.

Then, we can find the zeros by looking for all the $x$-values that make any of the factors equal to zero.

## Finding the zeros

So this is the factored form of $p$:

$p(x)=(x+3)(x+1)(x+2)(x-2)$

This table contains all the factors of $p$ and the $x$-values that make them equal to zero.

Factor | Zero
:-: | :-:
$(x+3)$ | $x=-3$
$(x+1)$ | $x=-1$
$(x+2)$ | $x=-2$
$(x-2)$ | $x=2$

We found that the zeros of $p$ are $x=-3$, $x=-1$, $x=-2$, and $x=2$, which means the graph has $x$-intercepts at $\left(-3,0\right)$, $\left(-1,0\right)$, $\left(-2,0\right)$, and $\left(2,0\right)$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: An x y coordinate plane. The x-axis scales by one half. Points are at (negative three, zero), (negative two, zero), (negative one, zero), and (two, zero).

question.content:
We want to find the zeros of this polynomial:

$p(x)=(x^2-9)(x^2+x-2)$

**Plot all the zeros ($x$-intercepts) of the polynomial in the interactive graph.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
First, we need to factor the polynomial entirely.

Then, we can find the zeros by looking for all the $x$-values that make any of the factors equal to zero.

## Finding the zeros

So this is the factored form of $p$:

$p(x)=(x+3)(x-3)(x+2)(x-1)$

This table contains all the factors of $p$ and the $x$-values that make them equal to zero.

Factor | Zero
:-: | :-:
$(x+3)$ | $x=-3$
$(x-3)$ | $x=3$
$(x+2)$ | $x=-2$
$(x-1)$ | $x=1$

We found that the zeros of $p$ are $x=-3$, $x=3$, $x=-2$, and $x=1$, which means the graph has $x$-intercepts at $\left(-3,0\right)$, $\left(3,0\right)$, $\left(-2,0\right)$, and $\left(1,0\right)$.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: An x y coordinate plane. The x-axis scales by one half. Points are at (negative three, zero), (negative two, zero), (one, zero), and (three, zero).
